I, material illustrating feudal concepts. Edward Jenks, Law and Politics in the Middle Ages (New York, 1898) is an old but still very readable analysis with emphasis on early concepts. SCHOLASTICISM: A good deal of medieval political writing cannot be understood without some knowledge of the categories and controversies of scholastic philosophy. Standard works are Maurice de Wulf, Histoire de la philosophie midi/vale
F. Savigny, Geschichte des romischen Rechts im Mittelalter

editor.literal: II. of Richard P. McKeon, ed.

title: Sabine, op
gives a bibliography that will serve to orient the reader in the characteristic ideas of Roman jurisprudence. The standard history of the influence of Roman law in the Middle Ages is still C
Paul Vinogradoff, Roman Law in Mediaeval Europe
is a useful introduction

collects many passages illustrating the concepts derived by the glossators from their study of Roman law. THE FATHERS: For the patristic sources of medieval thought, the student will depend for texts on the great collection of Migne, Patrologiae Cursus Completus, Series Latina (18«ff.) or on the useful selections and commentary in Carlyle, op
The best English translation of Augustine's City of God is that by Marcus Dods
Augustine's political ideas are variously interpreted; some useful studies are
The Political Aspects of St. Augustine's 'City of God'
Bernard Roland-Gosselin, La morale de saint-Augustin
Gustave Combes, La doctrine politique de St
Etienne Gilson, Introa duction l'etude de Saint-Augustin
Mittelalterliche Zeitanschauung in ihrem Einfluss auf PoUtik und Geschichtsschreibung
emphasizes the influence of Augustine on medieval theories of the relation of regnum and sacerdotium

is a good introduction to some of the concepts brought into medieval thought by the Germanic tradition. To the references cited there should be added a book of major importance: Fritz Kern, Gottesgniidentum und Widerstandsrecht im fruheren Mittelalter
this, together with a significant essay of Kern's, but without most of Kern's valuable notes, has been translated by S

Jacob, Essays in the Conciliar Epoch (Manchester, 1943; new ed., 1951), has useful material and comment. The older histories of the conciliar age tended to stress theory: e.g., Carl Joseph von Hefele, Conciliengeschichte (9 vols., Freiburg im Breisgau, 1873-1890),
